title: Two years and one Assassin's Creed Shadows later, Ubisoft is giving AC Mirage a "surprise" free DLC after saying it was done with the game
content:
Now that Assassin's Creed Shadows is in the wild, you'd think Ubisoft would be tunnel visioned into its DLC roadmap. Random as ever, the publisher's instead found the time to squeeze in some "surprise" additions into the last, slightly overlooked game in the series: Assassin's Creed Mirage.

"Assassin's Creed Mirage players, we have a surprise coming your way later this year," the company announced via a social media post. The free DLC will include a "new story chapter and missions set in 9th century AlUla," an ancient Saudi Arabian city, as well as "gameplay improvements for the base game and the new location." Our only official look at the whole thing is the concept art down below.

What makes this all so interesting is that Ubisoft said it had "no post-launch content" planned for AC Mirage in April, 2024. "Mirage [has been designed] as a standalone experience without any [DLC planned]," narrative director Stephane Boudon said at the time. "However, we have ideas on how we could extend the story of Basim, surely."

What changed between then and now? It's hard to tell, but the Mirage DLC was seemingly leaked a few months ago by a Les Echos report which also claimed the new content was born out of a partnership between Ubisoft and Savvy Games Group, a gaming conglomerate formed by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, which might explain the game's new location.

Fans have been feeding off more Mirage-shaped breadcrumbs, too. Notably, Assassin's Creed Mirage's Basim said he wants to be in Netflix's show, and fans think this could be "part of a calculated audience warm-up."

Here are 10 games like Assassin's Creed to take the leap of faith on
summary: Ubisoft is giving away a surprise free DLC to Assassin's Creed Mirage, the last game in the series, after stating it was done with the game. The company announced the DLC will include a new story chapter and missions set in 9th century AlUla, an ancient Saudi Arabian city, and gameplay improvements. Despite previously stating that there was no post-launch content planned for AC Mirage, this news has been revealed as a significant development. The news was reportedly leaked by a report suggesting it was part of a partnership between Ubisoft and Savvy Games Group, a gaming conglomerate formed by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, which may explain the game's new location.
shortSummary: Ubogracht Ubisoft is releasing a surprise free DLC for Assassin's Creed Mirage, featuring new story chapters, missions, and a new location in Saudi Arabia.

Assassin's Creed has gone a bit off the rails, but Ubisoft says it hasn't forgotten about the whole Assassins versus Templars thing, with a "deep dive" on the conflict coming "in the near future"
Now eventually you do plan to have Templars in your Assassins versus Templars game, right?
The Assassin's Creed series tends to have a flaky relationship with its own lore, as you can never be quite sure whether theoretical mainstays like modern-day shenanigans or Isu artifacts are going to appear in any given entry. Even the conflict between the Assassins and the Templars was more or less swept under the rug in Assassin's Creed Shadows, but Ubisoft is hinting that may soon change.
"The Assassins vs. Templars conflict has always been a core pillar of Assassin's Creed," a developer identified as Luc says in a Reddit AMA. "With Shadows, we wanted to properly set our protagonist in the setting before expanding on the Assassins vs. Templars. Now that it's done on the main game, we scratched the surface with the Critical Role story drop, and you can expect more deep dive in this conflict in the near future."
Shadows does technically feature a handful of Templars, but the organization is very much in the distant background of the game's main conflict. Luc's comment doesn't make clear when we'll see the return of the full Templar storyline, but the Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap currently only has a single major story DLC release on it – I'd say that free Claws of Awaji expansion is a pretty safe bet for some Templar action.
And yes, the Critical Role story drop Luc alludes to is indeed canon, though the Dead by Daylight crossover is not. Luc confirms as much in another comment, where the issue of Isu artifacts is also addressed. "The fact that there is no Isu artifact in the main game of Shadows doesn't mean that it doesn't exist in the world of Shadows; it just wasn't a story device that we needed for the story we wanted to tell," Luc says.
What about a return to the modern-day storyline? "While Modern Day is not the main focus of the story we tell with Shadows," Luc says in yet another comment, "it remains important for our community, so you can expect it to be expanded at some point, in some fashion…"
On the topic of both the Templars and the Isu, another dev identified as Simon notes that any specific details "would be a spoiler," but says to "keep an eye on our future updates – there might be more deep-lore secrets drops than you imagine…"
That's a whole lot of "someday" and "maybe" with regards to the central lore of Assassin's Creed, but it does at least sound like we can expect a big check-in with the Templars sooner rather than later. As an unapologetic enthusiast for the series' ancient aliens and bizarre sci-fi plot twists, I hope those "deep-lore secrets" are indeed bigger than I imagine.

Assassin's Creed Shadows developers are focusing on improving "what we already have," but they're adding at least one new open-world activity in post-launch updates
Ubisoft is far from done with Feudal Japan
Assassin's Creed Shadows might have dropped months ago at this point, but Ubisoft isn't done adding on to and improving the massive romp since some AC developers have teased that an expanded open-world activity is in the works.
The Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap is stuffed with incoming features, including a New Game Plus mode, mysterious collaborations, and the promising Claws of Awaji DLC due sometime later this year. But in between those more beefy content drops, the team is working on updates that improve things bit by bit.
In a new Reddit AMA, some members of the team teased what we can expect from these smaller, more regular updates still in the pipeline. When asked about potential open-world activities, like new mini-games or random encounters, game producer 'Andre' said there's at least "one activity we plan to expand in the future."
"More details to come on this one," they added. "Otherwise, we are not planning many brand-new additions to the open-world activities. Our focus is to work on what we already have got in play."
Ubisoft's commitment to improving what's already here probably explains why Discovery Tour, the cool educational mode seen in the series' other RPG mammoths, isn't coming to Shadows.
Still, it sounds like there are lots of other cool things on the horizon for Assassin's Creed Shadows and the series as a whole. For example, the whole Assassin's versus Templars thing that the stealthy-stabby franchise was built on apparently hasn't been forgotten and will pop back up "in the near future."

10 Games like Assassin's Creed to take a leap of faith on
Here are the best games like Assassin's Creed to play right now
When it comes to games like Assassin's Creed, there are plenty of options out there. Whether you're after more experiences that will let you put your stealthy skills to use, you enjoy parkouring, or you're looking to get your fill of exploration, we've brought together the best alternatives out there that you can get stuck into right now.
The long-running stealth series from Ubisoft has brought us a lot of different adventures set across different periods in history, from the very first games that introduced the hidden blade, to the more recent RPG incarnations, we still have some exciting upcoming Assassin's Creed games to look forward to. After Assassin's Creed Mirage took us to Baghdad in the 9th century, the newly released Assassin's Creed Shadows brings us to Feudal Japan. Next, there are also rumors of an upcoming setting of the 16th-century witch trials in Assassin's Creed Hexe.
But while we wait for what looks set to be one of the most exciting new games on the horizon, these games like Assassin's Creed are here to keep you busy. So get ready to take a leap of faith as we guide you through our pick of the 10 best games like Assassin's Creed you can play right now.
10 Games like Assassin's Creed You Can Play Today
10. Dishonored 2
Developer: Arkane Studios
Platform(s): PC, PS4, Xbox One
Arkane's Dishonored series will delight stealth-focused Assassin's Creed fans who enjoyed the more focused earlier entries in the series – where you couldn't just whip out dual scimitars and go to town on enemies. One of the finest modern Immersive Sims, Dishonored 2 is still a revolutionary stealth game with toy box levels designed for critical thinkers and tinkerers.
Whether you want to set traps, possess foes, or use acrobatics to get around a problem, Dishonored 2 offers you that bandwidth alongside some genius-level design, creating maps full of clever environmental storytelling - spaces begging to be explored. Sure, it's a harsh switch to the first-person perspective, but the stealth ethos of Creed is present here, a style you should be familiar with if you're an old-school stealth game fan. If you find yourself enjoying Assassin's Creed's stealth gameplay, Dishonored doubles down on that fun, and offers an engaging story to boot.
Read our Dishonored 2 review
Weekly digests, tales from the communities you love, and more
9. Uncharted 4
Developer: Naughty Dog
Platform(s): PS5, PS4, PC
Assassin's Creed's stealth gameplay has always taken first priority over its story, so perhaps you'd be interested in Uncharted 4, which takes inspiration from Creed's parkour clambering but delivers one of the best modern narratives in video games. A globe-trotting tale following pretend Archaeologist Nathan Drake (who secretly just likes to blow stuff up) as he deals with his most intrepid foe yet - settling down.
A moving story that melds emotional lows with adrenaline-pumping highs, Uncharted 4 will suit any Assassin's Creed fan who is looking for a little bit more oomph in the story department. It also has an incredibly cool rope-swinging mechanic. Think Tarzan, but with like… guns and explosives. Do yourself a favor and make sure you play one of the best Uncharted games.
Read our Uncharted 4 review
8. The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
Developer: Nintendo
Platform(s): Nintendo Switch
A game that quickly became near and dear to every early adopter's heart when it dropped alongside the Nintendo Switch in early 2017, The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild is an utter masterpiece, a holistic reinvention of Zelda that pushed the series away from the trappings of the past and into the future. It'd be hard to argue it doesn't evoke some of Assassin's Creed greatest qualities in its open-world design and clever climbing mechanics.
You can climb anything in Breath of the Wild, much like you can scale most structures in Rome in Assassin's Creed 2. Where Assassin's Creed offers chaos and bloodshed, Breath of the Wild is a breath of fresh serenity, and can be incredibly therapeutic and relaxing when you're not being chased by Cucco's or aggravating fire dragons. All these years later, it remains one of the best Switch games available; Breath of the Wild is an even sweeter deal for Assassin's Creed fans, who should feel right at home clambering up the face of cliffs across its 50-hour story.
Read our The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild review
7. Hitman 3
Developer: IO Interactive
Platform(s): PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S
If you're really all about the stealthy murder, Hitman 3 delivers it by the bucketload. The latest installment of the series takes you everywhere from a Knives Out style murder mystery in a mansion to hanging off the side of the tallest building in the world dressed as a waiter.
Hitman 3 might not deliver the same open-world exploration, but it does offer you the same wealth of choice when it comes to how you complete your objectives. Whether you're in a Berlin club or at a wine mixer, the game is a big old toybox of death to play with, with assassination methods far more sophisticated than a quick stab with a hidden blade.
Read our Hitman 3 review
6. Batman: Arkham Asylum
Developer: Rocksteady Studios
Platform(s): PC, PS4, Xbox One
Originally released in 2009, Batman: Arkham Asylum kicked off a series of modern DC games that are considered among the best Batman games in existence. In 2019 it's available as part of the Return to Arkham collection, remastered for next-gen consoles. Don't let its age fool you; this is a timeless classic that will delight comic-book fans and gadget-savvy Assassin's Creed players who enjoy the counter-based combat seen in Assassin's Creed Origins and Assassin's Creed Odyssey.
With an exciting linear narrative and a host of collectibles to pilfer for as you explore the dreaded Arkham Asylum, the world feels deceptively open, despite the game being on rails. Sneaking around atop gargoyles and swooping down to knock out goons is still as riveting as ever, especially for Assassin's Creed players who love to systematically wipe out a room with stealth tactics and smoke bombs.
Read our Batman: Arkham Asylum review
5. Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain
Developer: Kojima Productions
Platform(s): PC, PS4, Xbox One
Kojima's final game before moving on to Death Stranding, Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain, is his unfinished masterpiece, a bittersweet sayonara to the series, which was his baby, packed with adrenaline and plenty of stories left untold. Despite the unfortunate dramatics surrounding its release, it still holds up as one of the best stealth games, and whilst its modern setting doesn't reflect Assassin's Creed, it's toy-box design does.
It's so wonderfully fine-tuned and full of minuscule details to do with physics and enemy AI - you can really toy with your enemies in this game and make their grey matter unravel through mischievous stealth - whilst enjoying an action-packed story playing as Venom Snake. Also, if you enjoyed managing real estate and your wide net of assassins in Brotherhood and other later entries in the series, no doubt you will latch on to the meta game of Mother Base, raising your own troops and expanding your offshore dominion. The Phantom Pain is considered one of the best Metal Gear games for good reason!
4. Ghost of Tsushima
Developer: Sucker Punch
Platform(s): PS5, PS4, PC
Assassin's Creed is known for taking us across the annals of history, and if you're looking for another period piece to delve into that also features a fantastic stealth system and engaging combat, Ghost of Tsushima is well worth considering. From performing air kills from the tops of tents to sneaking through tall grass and taking out foes unawares, you'll be treading a lot of familiar ground in Sucker Punch's adventure as protagonist Jin Sakai.
Set in a beautiful open-world, you can expect to engage in sword duels, fight a myriad of enemies, and get swept up in a memorable journey that takes place in the late 13th century. And with the upcoming sequel Ghost of Yotei, there's never been a better time to check it out.
Read our Ghost of Tsushima review
3. Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice
Developer: FromSoftware
Platform(s): PC, PS4, Xbox One
Assassin's Creed games have recently started to use From Software's finest features as a muse to invigorate its tried-and-tested model, most notably in the combat department, with Origins and Odyssey offering up similar cat-and-mouse gameplay to Dark Souls. As a result, if you’ve played the most modern Creed games and you've enjoyed taking on enemies, you might want to dip into one of the best FromSoftware games – Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice.
With its focus on stealth and high maneuverability thanks to the grappling hook, it's the closest game in the Soulsborne roster to Assassin's Creed. Of course, it’s a lot more unforgiving than what you might be used to, but with most AC games being a pushover in the difficulty department, the bump in trouble might feel quite rewarding.
Read our Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice review
2. Mirror's Edge: Catalyst
Developer: DICE
Platform(s): PC, PS4, Xbox One
Dropping just one year after the original Assassin's Creed, Mirrors Edge still stands out as one of the most seminal parkour games that paved the way for many future open-world movement mechanics, with some of the most fluid animations and adrenaline-pumping set pieces curating a serious atmosphere in its neon-laden world.
Mirror's Edge Catalyst is the sequel that followed suit, and whilst stumbling at a few hurdles, it's well worth playing if you enjoy parkour games and would like to see the platforming performed from a different perspective from the one seen in Assassin's Creed, alongside a more involved narrative and tactile melee combat.
Read our Mirror's Edge Catalyst review
1. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt
Developer: CD Projekt RED
Platform(s): PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S
Easily one of the best open world games ever made, The Witcher 3 is an absolute behemoth of an RPG that absolutely influenced the reinvention of Assassin's Creed, from the combat to the scaling gear system.
Fans of Origins and Odyssey won't be too far from home when they step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, and will most likely delight in its bustling narrative and branching, lore-heavy side quests that enrich its enrapturing medieval world in a fashion that Assassin's Creed is still trying to capture. With potent character dynamics, a fleshed-out combat system, and some moving moments, you couldn't go wrong embarking on this epic 50-100-hour tale.
Read our The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt review

Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap, DLC and future content
Assassin's Creed Shadows is shaping up to be a huge game, but future DLC will make it even bigger
The Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap has been unveiled, showing off what Ubisoft is adding over the next few months. We already knew about the Claws of Awaji expansion, which will continue Yasuke and Naoe's story beyond the main quest of Assassin's Creed Shadows, but now we know that two Story Drops, new parkour moves, more difficulty options, and an expanded alarm will all be added first. There’s a lot to go over, so here's everything we know about future updates, expansions, and DLCs for Assassin's Creed Shadows.
Assassin's Creed Shadows update roadmap
Ubisoft has unveiled new post-launch content plans for Year 1 of Assassin’s Creed Shadows, which include new quests, parkour improvements, new game plus, and the previously announced Claws of Awaji expansion.
Unlike previous Assassin's Creed games, Shadows will not have a Season Pass which means that these content updates will be free, with the Claws of Awaji expansion (covered further below) and new store items being the only exceptions. These free updates will also be packed with new activities and features, as well as improvements to existing aspects of the game.
Here are all the updates Ubisoft has announced so far and when they’ll release for the Assassin’s Creed Shadows roadmap:
Early May
- First Story Drop, “The Works of Luis Frois”: A free update focused on learning more about the Jesuit scholar Luis Frois, who appears at various points in the main story, notably right at the beginning when Yasuke (then Diogo) is acting as a bodyguard.
- Codex update
- Quality-of-life improvements
Late May
- First Special Collaboration: Who this collaboration is with has not yet been announced.
- Parkour update: New height-gaining back-ejects, newly animated height-gaining side-ejects and an entirely new vertical ledge jump move. The latter is a simple vertical jump that lets bother characts grab overhangs and awnings.
- Photo Mode update: New filters, stickers, character poses, facial expressions, and even ambient music.
June
- Second Story Drop: New free quest and a new Assassin’s Creed Shadows Ally.
- New difficulty options
- Gameplay immersion options: You’ll be able to turn off weapon glints, black-and-white ability filters, assassination filter effects, and stealth outlines – for if Assassin’s Creed Shadows immersive mode hasn’t been enough.
- Open world alarm system: The alarm system will be expanded to make things tougher when you’re not in a castle – make sure you read our Assassin’s Creed Shadows Wanted level guide first.
- Headgear in cutscenes option: Allows you to choose whether your hoods, hats, and helmets for Naoe and Yasuke appear during cutscenes and conversations.
Later
- Claws of Awaji expansion
- Assassin’s Creed Shadows New Game+
- Community feedback updates
- More Story Drops, Special Collaborations, and Codex updates
- More Animus content: New items in the Exchange, new rewards, and new Assassin’s Creed Shadows Projects.
- New rewards
- New premium store items
Assassin's Creed Shadows Claws of Awaji expansion
The first Assassin's Creed Shadows expansion, Claws of Awaji, sees Naoe and Yasuke trapped on a mysterious island, the real-life Awaji Island west of Osaka. It will release "later in 2025" and is free to all players that pre-ordered Assassin’s Creed Shadows, but there is still no way to buy it separately for when it launches.
Naoe and Yasuke must reclaim a lost treasure while avoiding traps and ambushes from deadly new foes, the crafty Sanzoku Ippa. The expansion also introduces the Bō weapon type for Naoe – a staff for poking and beating opponents – and will feature new gear to loot and abilities to unlock. Ubisoft says it will provide "over 10 hours of additional content" and takes place after the ending of the main game.

Assassin's Creed Mirage's Basim wants to be in Netflix's show, and fans think this could be "part of a calculated audience warm-up"
It would be a great game to adapt
There's an Assassin's Creed series currently in development at Netflix, and the actor who voices Basim and lends him his face, Lee Majdoub, wants in on the action. He may not be a household name, but one fan doesn't think including him would be far-fetched.
The official Assassin's Creed Twitter account posted an update on the series, writing "Netflix has greenlit the live-action Assassin's Creed series! Robert Patino and David Wiener will co-showrun."
"I would be more than happy to 'work in the dark to serve the light' on this project," Majdoub quote tweets. "Just saying. Incase Netflix is listening."
Here's My Theory on the Upcoming Assassin's Creed Show from r/assassinscreed
Over on Reddit, one fan reckons including Basim could be a good idea. "What if this series is actually that rumored Mirage continuation the Saudis were funding?" they ask. "Could all of this just be part of a calculated audience warm-up – something that’s become pretty common in modern show marketing?"
Basim's outing in Assassin's Creed Mirage wasn't exactly a fan or critic favorite, but it did well enough and the story lends itself well to a TV show. It's essentially a detective series set against a backdrop of assassins. And, its cast already has film and TV experience.
Majdoub stars in the Sonic movies as Eggman's assistant, and assassin mentor Shohreh Aghdashloo was in The Expanse, as well as Penguin and a long list of other shows and games. She's a very prolific actor, and her voice adds tremendous gravitas to any character she portrays; she'd be great.
Mirage would also be a great game to adapt due to its compelling plot. It's just a detective mystery with assassins, what's not to love?
Whatever happens, let's hope this series is better than the movie that came out a few years ago. It was proof that just having Michael Fassbender in a film isn't enough to make it good.
For now, though, we'll have to wait and see. In the meantime, check out our ranking of the best Assassin's Creed games. I can never decide between 2 and Black Flag, I love them both so much.

The ultimate Assassin's Creed Shadows guide hub
Our AC Shadows guides have everything you need to know about being a 16th Century murderer
Our Assassin's Creed Shadows guide hub has everything you need to know about Naoe and Yasuke's adventures. We've got everything from tips and tricks and mission choices to help with exploration, puzzles, secrets and the best weapons to hunt down. While not quite as big as a behemoth like Valhalla or Odyssey, AC Shadows is still a big game with perhaps more freedom offered to players than any other game in the franchise before it. With so much to discover and uncover, we’ve collated every guide you'll need in our hub below, as well as every other tidbit that players might want to know about the latest chapter in the Assassin/Templar war.
Getting Started in Assassin's Creed Shadows
If you're looking for a selection of guides to help you get to grips with your first few hours in Assassin's Creed Shadows, or just to know what's ahead of you before you even start, these guides below will help acclimate you to the perils and possibilities ahead.
- Before you begin: You'll probably want to know what lies ahead on this grand journey, so why not check out our helpful guidelines on how long is Assassin's Creed Shadows, or discover what's waiting in the game's future with our Assassin’s Creed Shadows roadmap?
- Set up and gameplay options: There are several choices you make before you even start playing, based on what kind of experience you want. Assassin's Creed Shadows Canon Mode streamlines the story by taking away certain options, while the Assassin's Creed Shadows Immersive Mode option is all about changing the language used to feel more accurate to the time.
- Gameplay modes: If you're curious to know more about AC Shadows' options, you can discover to what degree Assassin's Creed Shadows multiplayer is included in the final package, as well as if there's a Assassin's Creed Shadows New Game Plus.
Gameplay Basics and Tutorials in Assassin's Creed Shadows
Once you have your Katana ready to go, there are many mechanics and systems at play in AC Shadows that are worth understanding if you want to make the most out of them, not just survive - but thrive.
- Navigating the world: First of all, our selection of basic Assassin's Creed Shadows tips will help players better understand how they should operate on a moment-to-moment basis. Or for a sense of the scale of exploration ahead of you, our Assassin's Creed Shadows map has the full layout of the world of Feudal Japan you'll be free to navigate! And if you're curious about the effects of the weather on that world, we've explained the new Assassin's Creed Shadows seasons system and what it changes.
- Interacting with NPCs: From questgivers to merchants, there are a lot of characters to find and meet. To understand the influence of your words, we've explained the slightly confusing Assassin's Creed Shadows dialogue symbols, or if you want to go in as a captain of industry, here's all the best Assassin's Creed Shadows money farming methods!
- Your base and scouts: Naoe and Yasuke have their own lair you can upgrade and customise, the best options for which are laid out in our guide on the Assassin's Creed Shadows Hideout. However, all of those will require you to farm hideout resources in Assassin's Creed Shadows, which we can explain how to do. And finally, one of the main functions of your base is as a place to house and direct the new Assassin's Creed Shadows scouts, which our guide covers here.
Equipment, upgrades and character powers in Assassin's Creed Shadows
Now you understand how to play AC Shadows, you need to learn how to master it, and how to make the most of those you're playing as.
- Naoe and Yasuke: Our two protagonists play very differently, with their own strengths or weaknesses, as listed in this page on the Assassin's Creed Shadows Naoe and Yasuke differences. Or if you're wondering when you can play as Yasuke, here's how to switch characters in Assassin's Creed Shadows.
- Levelling up skills and abilities: This game has two intertwined systems for leveling up - first you build up your Assassin's Creed Shadows Knowledge Points, then you earn the Assassin's Creed Shadows Mastery Points, both of which have different functions in-game. Our guides will explain them both to you, as well as how you can earn them quickly and improve fast. And of course, what's the best way to spend them? We've listed all the best Assassin's Creed Shadows skills to tell you where you should be putting all that effort.
- Equipment and Gear: Obviously we've got pages on the best Assassin's Creed Shadows weapons and best Assassin's Creed Shadows armor, but we've also got a page explaining how to upgrade weapons and armor in Assassin's Creed Shadow so it can match your current level, as not doing that would mean it'll stop being helpful after a while. Ubisoft hints at the future of Assassin's Creed's Basim but says "no post-launch content is planned for Mirage"
Will we get more Basim games in the future?
Ubisoft says it has plans for Assassin's Creed protagonist Basim but "no post-launch content is planned for Mirage."
As spotted by Gamespot, two of Assassin's Creed Mirage's developers - narrative director Stephane Boudon and art director Jean-Luc Sala - took part in a Reddit AMA and gave fans of protagonist Basim a glimmer of hope. When asked if the team ever considered developing DLC or storyline content for Mirage based on the community's positive reception, Boudon said: "Mirage [has been designed] as a standalone experience without any [DLC planned]."
The developer continues: "However, we have ideas on how we could extend the story of Basim, surely. But as of today, no post-launch content is planned for Mirage." Boudon's response is vague, but it does suggest that Ubisoft might not be completely done with Basim's story - just Assassin's Creed Mirage.
Comment from r/assassinscreed
There are plenty of other Assassin's Creed games in development, so it's always possible that Basim could appear in one of them. Not only have we got Assassin's Creed Hexe on the way, but also smaller projects like the upcoming mobile game Assassin's Creed Jade, which had a closed beta test last year, and Assassin's Creed Red, which is set in Japan and planned to launch sometime in 2025. The timelines around those games don't necessarily match up with Basim, but stranger things than a bit of temporal jumping have happened to the series in the past.
Elsewhere in the AMA, one user asked the team if they'd be interested in developing "old-school" Assassin's Creed games, to which Boudon said: "We work in the dark to serve the light," along with a winking emoji. It doesn't give us much to work with but at least we know that the studio is aware of the demand.

Assassin's Creed Mirage guide to master the ways of the Hidden Ones
With Assassin's Creed Mirage available to play now, here's everything you need to know from tips to collectibles, to story
Assassin's Creed Mirage sees you explore 9th Century Baghdad as young Basim as he learns the assassination skills of the Hidden Ones to take on the enigmatic Order of the Ancients. It's a huge change from the last entry in the entry in the series, with Ubisoft taking a back-to-basics approach that sends Assassin's Creed back its roots – plenty of stealth, acrobatic assassinations, and parkour in a big city environment.
Fans of the earliest adventures of Altaïr and Ezio will feel more at home in AC Mirage as it's a turn away from the expansive scope of the open worlds seen in Assassin's Creed Valhalla and Assassin's Creed Odyssey. That's one of the reasons Mirage became one of our most anticipated upcoming Assassin's Creed games. However, with a lot to get to grips with and still plenty of collectible items to collect, you might need some help as you play Assassin's Creed Mirage. That's why we've compiled all our tips and tricks into one Assassin's Creed Mirage guide.
Assassin's Creed Mirage review
In our Assassin's Creed Mirage review, we scored the game a 4/5 and praised Ubisoft for delivering on its pledge to deliver an installment which honored the series' roots. We found Mirage to be a compact, stealth-focused adventure that punishes anyone trying to go in loud, and it does so in a world that's always a delight to explore.
Read the full Assassin's Creed Mirage review.

How long is Assassin's Creed Mirage?
Offering a much more compact experience compared to the previous RPG-like titles, the Assassin's Creed Mirage length is much shorter than those games. Most players should be able to get through the whole story in around 20 hours, but your completion time will vary depending on how much time you spend exploring Baghdad.
Assassin's Creed Mirage tips
With a lot of old mechanics brought back and made new and other mechanics stripped out, there's a fair bit to get used to when starting the game, so these 10 Assassin's Creed Mirage tips will help you learn the ropes of the Hidden Ones.
Assassin's Creed Mirage outfits
Basim can be dressed up in a plethora of Assassin's Creed Mirage outfits and costumes, with outfits providing unique perks to buff Basim's abilities too. We've laid out the full list of outfits and costumes in the linked guide, including any special Ubisoft Connect and microtransaction ones.
Be sure to also keep an eye out for Mysterious Shards (more on those below) in Baghdad to help you find the Assassin's Creed Mirage secret armor and weapons. These offer some really unique perks that are well worth picking up as early as possible.

As well as some improvements from his outfits, Basim also gets 23 Skills across three trees to unlock, providing lots of nice enhancements to his assassination abilities. However, with so much choice, it can be hard to know which Skills are good and worth unlocking or working towards, so our Assassin's Creed Mirage best Skills guide will help you know where to focus.
Assassin's Creed Mirage collectibles
It wouldn't be an Assassin's Creed game without lots of collectibles and AC Mirage is no different with several different types available:

Assassin's Creed Mirage story and missions
With lots of little cases and investigations to work through, Assassin's Creed Mirage has a short but varied story that involves going all over Baghdad, utilizing different mechanics in the game to get the information you need and assassinate those key targets:

The ending to Assassin's Creed Mirage is quite confusing and leaves a lot of unanswered questions, especially if you've not played Assassin's Creed Valhalla. Ubisoft unveils "updated" Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap with New Game+ and level cap boost, again vindicating my plan to wait months if not years to play new Ubisoft games
The Claws of Awaji DLC also has a fresh September release date
Ubisoft has revealed an "updated" Assassin's Creed Shadows roadmap detailing what's to come for the open-world RPG this summer and beyond.
"This summer, it's all about progression," Ubisoft says on its official website.
Kicking things off next week, Assassin's Creed Shadows is officially getting its New Game+ mode on July 29. The mode will be available once you beat the main story and the credits roll, resetting your progression and discovered locations but letting you keep your character level, gear, skill points, Knowledge rank, and Hideout progression.
New Game+ will also give you the option to skip the game's prologue entirely, and you won't be bothered by any of the tutorial sections that were there in your first playthrough.
Also on July 29, Assassin's Creed Shadows is getting its first level cap increase, from 60 to 80 for all players regardless of whether they're playing New Game+ or not. The "Progression Update" will also add new Knowledge Ranks, Mastery and Knowledge Skill ranks, and new upgrades for all Hideout buildings.
The July 29 update will also add the new Project 3 to the Animus menu, bringing along new resources, data files, and exclusive Animus-themed rewards.
Coming at the beginning of September, the game's newly revealed "quality-of-life improvement update" will add "some of the most requested features from our community" since launch. This update will let you skip time of day from dusk 'til dawn and vice-versa, and it'll unfog the map when you do a viewpoint synchronization. It'll also uncap the frame rate on PC, add some upgrades to the Hideout, add the new Mythic and Artifact upgrade levels to Forge, and add "additional goodies that may be familiar to long-time series fans."
Weekly digests, tales from the communities you love, and more
Finally, there's no more guessing as to when the game's first expansions, Claws of Awaji, is coming out. Ubisoft has officially set a September 16 release date for the DLC, free for everyone who pre-ordered Assassin's Creed Shadows.
By no means is this sort of thing unique to Ubisoft games, but boy am I feeling mighty vindicated in my decision to hold off on playing Assassin's Creed Shadows at launch. It wasn't easy; a AAA open-world game set in feudal Japan is very much my jam; but I feel like a lot of these post-launch features could've, and maybe should've, been there day one. Or, maybe, that's just what I tell myself when I know I have a dozen great games in my backlog and simply don't have time for another 60-hour game.
